data.title: Prouhet-Thue-Morse  suite
data.solution:
a = int(input())
b = int(input())

b += 1

suite = [-1]*b
suite[0] = 0

for i in range(0, b):
    try:
        suite[2*i] = suite[i]
        suite[2*i+1] = 1-suite[i]
    except:
        pass

print(int(''.join([str(v) for v in suite[a:b+1]]), 2))
data.statement:
The Prouhet-Thue-Morse suite is composed of 1 and 0. <<t(0) = 0>> and the other digits are defined by <<t(2n)=t(n) and t(2n+1)=1-t(n)>>. 

The first terms of the suite are <<011010011001...>>

If we take the numbers between t(3) and t(8), we get : <<010011>> which is <<19>> in base 10.

Given [[a]] and [[b]], two strictly positive integers (b > a), output the number represented by the digits from t([[a]]) to t([[b]]).
data.stubGenerator:
read a:int
read b:int
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<line 1:>> : the first strictly positive integer [[a]] representing the starting index of t suite
<<line 2:>> : the second strictly positive integer [[b]] greater than [[a]] representing the ending index of t suite
data.outputDescription: The integer in base 10 represented by the digits from t([[a]]) to t([[b]])

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The Prouhet-Thue-Morse suite is composed of 1 and 0. t(0) = 0 and the other digits are defined by t(2n)=t(n) and t(2n+1)=1-t(n).

The first terms of the suite are 011010011001...

If we take the numbers between t(3) and t(8), we get : 010011 which is 19 in base 10.

Given a and b, two strictly positive integers (b > a), output the number represented by the digits from t(a) to t(b).
Input
line 1: : the first strictly positive integer a representing the starting index of t suite
line 2: : the second strictly positive integer b greater than a representing the ending index of t suite
Output
The integer in base 10 represented by the digits from t(a) to t(b)
Constraints
0 < a ≤ 100000
1 < b ≤ 100000
b > a
output < 10^11
Example
Input
3
8
Output
19
